app.note: According to KRR's note, the scribe apparently left out the last two syllables of the fourth quarter. The date of Narendra-Mr̥garāja's reign is variously given in related grants as 40, 44 or 48 years, of which 44 is the rarest and 48 is the most common. Variants of this stanza exist with the endings catvāriṁśat samāṣṭabhiḥ, catvāriṁśat samās samaḥ and sa-catvāriṁśad aṣṭakam, each of which is attested once that I know of. Given the predominance of 48 in the prose versions of the genealogy and the fact that the existence of variants in this stanza may be explained by an effort to eliminate the non-standard sandhi in the presumable original catvāriṁśat samāṣṭabhiḥ, I am tempted to restore this text here. Scholars disagree about the length of Narendra-Mr̥garāja's reign, and Krishna Rao (269-270; 27-28) argues vehemently for 40. He apparently accepts this record as another piece of evidence for 40 years, which is definitely not acceptable, since the omitted characters could have corresponded to any of the versions cited here. I thus prefer not to restore anything here. Since no image of this page is available, it is also possible that the text shown by KRR as unclear is wholly illegible, and the allegedly omitted characters are actually present, perhaps compressed or added between the lines.

The reading adopted here was offered, with full confidence, by an editorial footnote to KRR's edition. KRR's original restoration does not look very intelligible to me; they may have meant to restore triṁśad abdān krameṇa.

KRR's edition shows no punctuation here, but has a footnote saying, Mark of punctuation is not necessary here. I assume that a mark is present in the original, but the footnote anchor may also be a typo (the same anchor is used several times on this page next to punctuation marks present in the text that KRR consider superfluous).
Though the verse is intelligible as read by KRR, I would prefer to emend to taj-jaḥ here, or to read this if the plate permits.
Since adhibala seems to be attested only as a technical term in drama, I prefer to emend.
The metre requires a short vowel here.

The reading adopted here is shown (as clear) in a footnote signed N. L. R. in KRR's edition. I do not know who its author may be. In the published photo, nr̥pa is clear, aḫ pa is at least more plausible than jita, and ra is almost clear.
The dot that KRR reads as an anusvāra is above ṇṭha, so it is probably damage, and the punctuation mark was placed before the conjunct as in line 18 above and several times below.

I adopt KRR's reading, which he prints as clear throughout. I have difficulty interpreting this text, but alternatives I could come up with do not improve it, e.g. -acalā-sthair; -acalās tair; -acalāstrair. If KRR's reading is correct, it should perhaps be construed as gguṇa-vapur-acalā-svair or emended to gguṇa-vapur-acalāḥ svair.

The superfluous character looks more like ri than vi to me, and I assume it was deleted in the original, perhaps on account of being too close to the hole. I accept KRR's reading of the i-s as short, but either or both may in fact be long, and it is also possible that ri was re-engraved to correct girīśa to giriśa or vice versa.
It is also possible to read dhammādhyakṣa here, but there is definitely not both a repha and an ā.

The subscript th resembles t with the tail extended into a nearly full circle. It is not the regular shape of th, but clearly distinct from t and identical to the one (read as th by RKK) in sthāna earlier in this line.
